author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: U2 sued for allegedly stealing song for ‘Achtung Baby'
text:
ET Tu, U2?
A British songwriter and composer filed a lawsuit in Manhattan federal court Monday against the Irish band U2, alleging it stole one of his songs for the 1991 album “Achtung Baby.”
Paul Rose, who now lives in New York, names lead singer Bono and bandmates The Edge, Adam Clayton and Larry Mullen Jr. as well as Island Records in the suit.
A well-known musician in his own right — with 12 solo albums — Rose is seeking $5 million plus attorney fees, the suit said.
Paul McCartney files lawsuit to reacquire Beatles copyrights 
U2 has never given Rose a writer’s credit or acknowledged his role in creating the music — which became “The Fly,” the seventh song on “Achtung Baby” — the suit said.
“Defendants have knowingly been exploiting ‘The Fly’ without crediting Rose as a writer for more than 25 years,” the suit said.
Rose was never able to capitalize on the success of the song to boost his professional profile either, attorney Thomas Mullaney noted.
In his suit, Rose said he wrote the music in 1989 while living in England. He called it “Nae Slappin.” He had it copyrighted two years later.
After recording the song on a demo tape in 1989, Rose circulated it through his agent to several senior executives at Island Records, the suit said.
Rose’s song was “played and repeatedly listened to in the Island Records office,” the suit said.
British songwriter and composer Paul Rose says he never received credit for "The Fly," a song on "Achtung Baby." (YouTube via Paul Rose) U2 was also signed by Island Records in 1989 and the band was “often in the Island Records offices” and Bono and The Edge used the company’s recording studio, the suit said.
In 1990, U2 began recording sessions for “Achtung Baby,” the suit said. The record was a total departure from the band’s prior style — exploring a dark and edgy sound to capture a new audience.
U2 released “The Fly” as the first single on Oct. 21, 1991 — roughly a monthly before “Achtung Baby” dropped.
The song’s “dance beats, distorted vocals and hard industrial edge sounded nothing like typical U2” — and that’s because Rose wrote it, the suit said.
The key elements of “The Fly” — the guitar hook and the distinctive guitar solo and the percussive beats — are nearly identical to “Nae Slappin,” court papers said.
“The Fly” copied and incorporated substantial, distinct, important and recognizable portions of Plaitiff’s work,” Rose’s suit said.
“An ordinary lay observer would reasonably find that ... infringement has occurred. Indeed, the similarities .... are so strikingly similar that independent creation is precluded,” the suit concluded.
No reason is given for Rose’s 25-year delay in filing his claim, but the suit notes he’s had no recourse because “the right of attribution is not statutorily recognized.”
Island Records and U2 could not be immediately reached for comment.
